title: Vaccine controversies
cleaned_text: Vaccine controversies [Jump to navigation](#mw-head) [Jump to search](#searchInput) Vaccine controversies are public debates concerning the medical, ethical, and legal issues related to [vaccines](/w/index.php?title=Vaccines&action=edit&redlink=1). These controversies have occurred since almost 80 years before the terms vaccine and vaccination were introduced. Such controversies often involve concerns about vaccine safety, despite the strong [scientific consensus](/w/index.php?title=Scientific_consensus&action=edit&redlink=1) that the benefits of vaccination greatly outweigh the risks. [[1]](#cite_note-1) [[2]](#cite_note-2) Misplaced fears of serious [adverse effects](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_adverse_event&action=edit&redlink=1) lead to [vaccines cause autism](/w/index.php?title=Folk_epidemiology_of_autism&action=edit&redlink=1) has been widely disproven by scientific evidence, yet still leads some parents to delay or avoid vaccinating their children. Controversies may also involve [vaccine policy](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_policy&action=edit&redlink=1), for example there is some concern that mandatory vaccination violates [civil liberties](/w/index.php?title=Civil_liberties&action=edit&redlink=1) or reduces public trust in vaccination. [[5]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-5) [[9]](#cite_note-9) [[10]](#cite_note-10) Variolation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=1)] Early attempts to prevent smallpox involved deliberate [inoculation](/w/index.php?title=Inoculation&action=edit&redlink=1) with the disease in hopes that a mild case would confer immunity. Originally called inoculation, this technique was later called [variolation](/w/index.php?title=Variolation&action=edit&redlink=1) to avoid confusion with cowpox inoculation ( [vaccination](/w/index.php?title=Vaccination&action=edit&redlink=1)) when that was introduced by [Edward Jenner](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit&redlink=1). Although variolation had a long history in China and India, it was first used in North America and England in 1721. [Reverend Cotton Mather](/w/index.php?title=Cotton_Mather&action=edit&redlink=1) introduced variolation to Boston, Massachusetts, during the 1721 smallpox epidemic. [[11]](#cite_note-VaccineControversy-11) Despite strong opposition in the community, [[12]](#cite_note-Early-12) Mather convinced Dr. [Zabdiel Boylston](/w/index.php?title=Zabdiel_Boylston&action=edit&redlink=1) to try it. Boylston first experimented on his 6-year-old son, his slave, and his slave's son; each subject contracted the disease and was sick for several days, until the sickness vanished and they were "no longer gravely ill". [[11]](#cite_note-VaccineControversy-11) Boylston went on to variolate thousands of Massachusetts residents, and many places were named for him in gratitude as a result. [Lady Mary Wortley Montagu](/w/index.php?title=Lady_Mary_Wortley_Montagu&action=edit&redlink=1) introduced variolation to England. She had seen it used in Turkey and, in 1718, had her son successfully variolated in Constantinople under the supervision of Dr. [Charles Maitland](/w/index.php?title=Charles_Maitland_(physician)&action=edit&redlink=1). When she returned to England in 1721, she had her daughter variolated by Maitland. This aroused considerable interest, and Sir [Hans Sloane](/w/index.php?title=Hans_Sloane&action=edit&redlink=1) organized the variolation of some inmates in [Newgate Prison](/w/index.php?title=Newgate_Prison&action=edit&redlink=1). These were successful, and after a further short trial in 1722, two daughters of [Caroline of Ansbach](/w/index.php?title=Caroline_of_Ansbach&action=edit&redlink=1) Princess of Wales were variolated without mishap. With this royal approval, the procedure became common when smallpox epidemics threatened. [[13]](#cite_note-williams-13) [Religious arguments against inoculation](/w/index.php?title=Vaccination_and_religion&action=edit&redlink=1) were soon advanced. For example, in a 1772 sermon entitled "The Dangerous and Sinful Practice of Inoculation", the English theologian Reverend Edmund Massey argued that diseases are sent by God to punish sin and that any attempt to prevent smallpox via inoculation is a "diabolical operation". [[12]](#cite_note-Early-12) It was customary at the time for popular preachers to publish sermons, which reached a wide audience. This was the case with Massey, whose sermon reached North America, where there was early religious opposition, particularly by [John Williams](/w/index.php?title=John_Williams_(minister)&action=edit&redlink=1). A greater source of opposition there was Dr. [William Douglass](/w/index.php?title=William_Douglass_(physician)&action=edit&redlink=1), a medical graduate of [Edinburgh University](/w/index.php?title=Edinburgh_University&action=edit&redlink=1) and a [Fellow of the Royal Society](/w/index.php?title=Fellow_of_the_Royal_Society&action=edit&redlink=1), who had settled in Boston. [[13]](#cite_note-williams-13):114-122 Smallpox vaccination[ in declined and was banned in some countries. [[14]](#cite_note-14) [[15]](#cite_note-15) As with variolation, there was some religious opposition to vaccination, although this was balanced to some extent by support from clergymen, such as Reverend Robert Ferryman, a friend of Jenner's, and [Rowland Hill](/w/index.php?title=Rowland_Hill_(preacher)&action=edit&redlink=1), [[13]](#cite_note-williams-13):221 who not only preached in its favour but also performed vaccination themselves. There was also opposition from some variolators who saw the loss of a lucrative monopoly. William Rowley published illustrations of deformities allegedly produced by vaccination, lampooned in [James Gillray](/w/index.php?title=James_Gillray&action=edit&redlink=1)'s famous caricature depicted on this page, and Benjamin Moseley likened cowpox to [syphilis](/w/index.php?title=Syphilis&action=edit&redlink=1), starting a controversy that would last into the 20th century. [[13]](#cite_note-williams-13):203-205 There was legitimate concern from supporters of vaccination about its safety and efficacy, but this was overshadowed by general condemnation, particularly when legislation started to introduce compulsory vaccination. The reason for this was that vaccination was introduced before laboratory methods were developed to control its production and account for its failures. [[16]](#cite_note-baxby2001-16) Vaccine was maintained initially through arm-to-arm transfer and later through production on the skin of animals, and bacteriological sterility was impossible. Further, identification methods for potential pathogens were not available until the late 19th to early 20th century. Diseases later shown to be caused by contaminated vaccine included [erysipelas](/w/index.php?title=Erysipelas&action=edit&redlink=1), [tuberculosis](/w/index.php?title=Tuberculosis&action=edit&redlink=1), [tetanus](/w/index.php?title=Tetanus&action=edit&redlink=1), and syphilis. This last, though rare—estimated at 750 cases in 100 million vaccinations [[17]](#cite_note-bazin2000-17)—attracted particular attention. Much later, Dr. [Charles Creighton](/w/index.php?title=Charles_Creighton&action=edit&redlink=1), a leading medical opponent of vaccination, claimed that the vaccine itself was a cause of syphilis and devoted a book to the subject. [[18]](#cite_note-creighton-18) As cases of smallpox started to occur in those who had been vaccinated earlier, supporters of vaccination pointed out that these were usually very mild and occurred years after the vaccination. In turn, opponents of vaccination pointed out that this contradicted Jenner's belief that vaccination conferred complete protection. [[16]](#cite_note-baxby2001-16):17-21 The views of opponents of vaccination that it was both dangerous and ineffective led to the development of determined anti-vaccination movements in England when legislation was introduced to make vaccination compulsory. [[19]](#cite_note-williamson-19) England[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=3)] Because of its greater risks, [variolation](/w/index.php?title=Variolation&action=edit&redlink=1) was banned in England by the 1840 [Vaccination Act](/w/index.php?title=Vaccination_Act&action=edit&redlink=1), which also introduced free voluntary vaccination for infants. Thereafter Parliament passed successive acts to enact and enforce compulsory vaccination. [[20]](#cite_note-porter-20) The 1853 act introduced compulsory vaccination, with fines for non-compliance and imprisonment for non-payment. The 1867 act extended the age requirement to 14 years and introduced repeated fines for repeated refusal for the same child. Initially, vaccination regulations were organised by the local [Poor Law](/w/index.php?title=Poor_Law&action=edit&redlink=1) Guardians, and in towns where there was strong opposition to vaccination, sympathetic Guardians were elected who did not pursue prosecutions. This was changed by the 1871 act, which required Guardians to act. This significantly changed the relationship between the government and the public, and organized protests increased. [[20]](#cite_note-porter-20) In [Keighley](/w/index.php?title=Keighley&action=edit&redlink=1), Yorkshire, in 1876 the Guardians were arrested and briefly imprisoned in [York](/w/index.php?title=York&action=edit&redlink=1) Castle, prompting large demonstrations in support of the "Keighley Seven". [[19]](#cite_note-williamson-19):108-109 The protest movements crossed social boundaries. The financial burden of fines fell hardest on the working class, who would provide the largest numbers at public demonstrations. [[21]](#cite_note-21) Societies and publications were organized by the middle classes, and support came from celebrities such as [George Bernard Shaw](/w/index.php?title=George_Bernard_Shaw&action=edit&redlink=1) and [Alfred Russel Wallace](/w/index.php?title=Alfred_Russel_Wallace&action=edit&redlink=1), doctors such as Picton](/w/index.php?title=James_Allanson_Picton&action=edit&redlink=1). [[20]](#cite_note-porter-20) By 1885, with over 3,000 prosecutions pending in [Leicester](/w/index.php?title=Leicester&action=edit&redlink=1), a mass rally there was attended by over 20,000 protesters. [[22]](#cite_note-baxby1999-22) Under increasing pressure, the government appointed a Royal Commission on Vaccination in 1889, which issued six reports between 1892 and 1896, with a detailed summary in 1898. [[23]](#cite_note-23) Its recommendations were incorporated into the 1898 Vaccination Act, which still required compulsory vaccination but allowed exemption on the grounds of conscientious objection on presentation of a certificate signed by two magistrates. [[5]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-5) [[20]](#cite_note-porter-20) These were not easy to obtain in towns where magistrates supported compulsory vaccination, and after continued protests, a further act in 1907 allowed exemption on a simple signed declaration. [[22]](#cite_note-baxby1999-22) Although this solved the immediate problem, the compulsory vaccination acts remained legally enforceable, and determined opponents lobbied for their repeal. An end to compulsory vaccination was one of the demands of the [1900 Labour Party General Election Manifesto](/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom_general_election,_1900&action=edit&redlink=1). [[24]](#cite_note-24) This was done as a matter of routine when the [National Health Service](/w/index.php?title=National_Health_Service&action=edit&redlink=1) was introduced in 1948, with "almost negligible" opposition from supporters of compulsory vaccination. [[25]](#cite_note-millard1948-25) Vaccination in Wales was covered by English legislation, but the [Scottish legal system](/w/index.php?title=Scottish_legal_system&action=edit&redlink=1) was separate. Vaccination was not made compulsory there until 1863, and conscientious objection was allowed after vigorous protest only in 1907. [[16]](#cite_note-baxby2001-16):10-11 In the late 19th century, the city of [Leicester](/w/index.php?title=Leicester&action=edit&redlink=1) in the UK received much attention because of the way smallpox was managed there. There was particularly strong opposition to compulsory vaccination, and medical authorities had to work within this framework. They developed a system that did not use vaccination but was based on the notification of cases, the strict isolation of patients and contacts, and the provision of isolation hospitals. [[26]](#cite_note-26) This proved successful but required acceptance of compulsory isolation rather than vaccination. [C. Killick Millard](/w/index.php?title=C._Killick_Millard&action=edit&redlink=1), initially a supporter of compulsory vaccination, was appointed [Medical Officer of Health](/w/index.php?title=Medical_Officer_of_Health&action=edit&redlink=1) in 1901. He moderated his views on compulsion but encouraged contacts and his staff to accept vaccination. This approach, developed initially due to overwhelming opposition to government mandates, became known as the Leicester Method. [[25]](#cite_note-millard1948-25) [[27]](#cite_note-fraser-27) In time it became generally accepted as the most appropriate way to deal with smallpox outbreaks and was listed as one of the "important events in the history of smallpox control" by those most involved in the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization)'s successful [Smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox) Eradication Campaign. The final stages of the campaign, generally referred to as "surveillance containment", owed much to the Leicester method. [[28]](#cite_note-28) States[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=4)] In the US, President [Thomas Jefferson](/w/index.php?title=Thomas_Jefferson&action=edit&redlink=1) took a close interest in vaccination, alongside Dr. Waterhouse, chief physician at Boston. Jefferson encouraged the development of ways to transport vaccine material through the Southern states, which included measures to avoid damage by heat, a leading cause of ineffective batches. [Smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox) outbreaks were contained by the latter half of the 19th century, a development widely attributed to the vaccination of a large portion of the population. Vaccination rates fell after this decline in smallpox cases, and the disease again became epidemic in the late 19th century (see [Smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox)). [[30]](#cite_note-30) After an 1879 visit to New York by prominent British anti-vaccinationist [William Tebb](/w/index.php?title=William_Tebb&action=edit&redlink=1), The Anti-Vaccination Society of America was founded. [[31]](#cite_note-31) [[32]](#cite_note-history-32) The New England Anti-Compulsory Vaccination League formed in 1882, and the Anti-Vaccination League of New York City in 1885. [[32]](#cite_note-history-32) Tactics in the US largely followed those used in England. [[33]](#cite_note-33) Vaccination in the US was regulated by individual states, in which there followed a progression of compulsion, opposition, and repeal similar to that in England. [[34]](#cite_note-34) Although generally organized on a state-by-state basis, the vaccination controversy reached the [US Supreme Court](/w/index.php?title=US_Supreme_Court&action=edit&redlink=1) in 1905. There, in the case of [Jacobson v. Massachusetts](/w/index.php?title=Jacobson_v._Massachusetts&action=edit&redlink=1), the court ruled that states have the authority to require vaccination against smallpox during a smallpox epidemic. [[35]](#cite_note-35) [John Pitcairn](/w/index.php?title=John_Pitcairn,_Jr.&action=edit&redlink=1), the wealthy founder of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company (now [PPG Industries](/w/index.php?title=PPG_Industries&action=edit&redlink=1)), emerged as a major financier and leader of the American anti-vaccination movement. On March 5, 1907, in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, he delivered an address to the Committee on Public Health and Sanitation of the [Pennsylvania General Assembly](/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania_General_Assembly&action=edit&redlink=1) criticizing vaccination. [[36]](#cite_note-vaccination_address-36) He later sponsored the National Anti-Vaccination Conference, which, held in Philadelphia in October 1908, led to the creation of The Anti-Vaccination League of America. When the league organized later that month, members chose Pitcairn as their first president. [[37]](#cite_note-Horrors-37) On December 1, 1911, Pitcairn was appointed by Pennsylvania Governor [John K. Tener](/w/index.php?title=John_K._Tener&action=edit&redlink=1) to the Pennsylvania State Vaccination Commission, and subsequently authored a detailed report strongly opposing the commission's conclusions. [[37]](#cite_note-Horrors-37) He remained a staunch opponent of vaccination until his death in 1916. Brazil[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=5)] In November 1904, in response to years of inadequate sanitation and disease, followed by a poorly explained public health campaign led by the renowned Brazilian public health official [Oswaldo Cruz](/w/index.php?title=Oswaldo_Cruz&action=edit&redlink=1), citizens and military cadets in [Rio de Janeiro](/w/index.php?title=Rio_de_Janeiro&action=edit&redlink=1) arose in a Revolta da Vacina, or [Vaccine Revolt](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_Revolt&action=edit&redlink=1). Riots broke out on the day a vaccination law took effect; vaccination symbolized the most feared and most tangible aspect of a public health plan that included other features, such as urban renewal, that many had opposed for years. [[38]](#cite_note-38) Later vaccines and antitoxins[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=6)] Opposition to smallpox vaccination continued into the 20th century and was joined by controversy over new vaccines and the introduction of [antitoxin](/w/index.php?title=Antitoxin&action=edit&redlink=1) treatment for [diphtheria](/w/index.php?title=Diphtheria&action=edit&redlink=1). Injection of horse serum into humans as used in antitoxin can cause [hypersensitivity](/w/index.php?title=Hypersensitivity&action=edit&redlink=1), commonly referred to as [serum sickness](/w/index.php?title=Serum_sickness&action=edit&redlink=1). Moreover, the continued production of smallpox vaccine in animals and the production of antitoxins in horses prompted [anti-vivisectionists](/w/index.php?title=Anti-vivisectionist&action=edit&redlink=1) to oppose vaccination. [[39]](#cite_note-39) Diphtheria antitoxin was serum from horses that had been immunized against diphtheria, and was used to treat human cases by providing [passive immunity](/w/index.php?title=Passive_immunity&action=edit&redlink=1). In 1901, antitoxin from a horse named [Jim](/w/index.php?title=Jim_(horse)&action=edit&redlink=1) was contaminated with [tetanus](/w/index.php?title=Tetanus&action=edit&redlink=1) and killed 13 children in [St Louis](/w/index.php?title=St_Louis&action=edit&redlink=1), Missouri. This incident, together with nine deaths from tetanus from contaminated smallpox vaccine in [Camden, New Jersey](/w/index.php?title=Camden,_New_Jersey&action=edit&redlink=1), led directly to the passing of the Control who have had [tuberculosis](/w/index.php?title=Tuberculosis&action=edit&redlink=1), it produces a [hypersensitivity](/w/index.php?title=Hypersensitivity&action=edit&redlink=1) reaction, and is still used to detect those who have been infected. However, Koch used tuberculin as a vaccine. This caused serious reactions and deaths in individuals whose latent tuberculosis was reactivated by the tuberculin. [[41]](#cite_note-41) This was a major setback for supporters of new vaccines. [[16]](#cite_note-baxby2001-16):30-31 Such incidents and others ensured that any untoward results concerning vaccination and related procedures received continued publicity, which grew as the number of new procedures increased. [[42]](#cite_note-42) In 1955, in a tragedy known as the [Cutter incident](/w/index.php?title=Cutter_incident&action=edit&redlink=1), [Cutter Laboratories](/w/index.php?title=Cutter_Laboratories&action=edit&redlink=1) produced 120,000 doses of the [Salk polio vaccine](/w/index.php?title=Salk_polio_vaccine&action=edit&redlink=1) that inadvertently contained some live polio virus along with inactivated virus. This vaccine caused 40,000 cases of polio, 53 cases of paralysis, and five deaths. The disease spread through the recipients' families, creating a polio epidemic that led to a further 113 cases of [paralytic polio](/w/index.php?title=Paralytic_polio&action=edit&redlink=1) and another five deaths. It was one of the worst pharmaceutical disasters in US history. [[43]](#cite_note-43) Later 20th-century events included the 1982 broadcast of DPT: Vaccine Roulette, which sparked debate over the safety of the [DPT vaccine](/w/index.php?title=DPT_vaccine&action=edit&redlink=1), [[44]](#cite_note-44) and the 1998 publication of a fraudulent academic article by [Andrew Wakefield](/w/index.php?title=Andrew_Wakefield&action=edit&redlink=1) [[45]](#cite_note-Goldacre-2008-45) which sparked the [MMR vaccine controversy](/w/index.php?title=MMR_vaccine_controversy&action=edit&redlink=1). Also recently, the [HPV vaccine](/wiki/HPV_vaccine) has become controversial due to concerns that it may encourage promiscuity when given to 11- and 12-year-old girls. [[46]](#cite_note-46) [[47]](#cite_note-47) Arguments against vaccines in the 21st century are often similar to those of 19th-century anti-vaccinationists. [[5]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-5) Studies done during 2008-2010s suggest that higher education levels and socioecomonic status of parents were associated with lower completion rates for vaccination. [[48]](#cite_note-48) [[49]](#cite_note-49) [[50]](#cite_note-50) [[51]](#cite_note-51) [[52]](#cite_note-52) Effectiveness[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=7)] Scientific evidence for effectiveness of large-scale vaccination campaigns is well established. [[53]](#cite_note-53) Vaccination campaigns helped eradicate [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox), which once killed as many as one in seven children in [Europe](/w/index.php?title=Europe&action=edit&redlink=1), [[54]](#cite_note-Fenner-54) and have nearly [eradicated polio](/w/index.php?title=Poliomyelitis_eradication&action=edit&redlink=1). [[55]](#cite_note-55) As a more modest example, infections caused by [Haemophilus influenzae](/w/index.php?title=Haemophilus_influenzae&action=edit&redlink=1), a major cause of [bacterial meningitis](/w/index.php?title=Bacterial_meningitis&action=edit&redlink=1) and other serious diseases in children, have decreased by over 99% in the US since the introduction of a vaccine in 1988. [[56]](#cite_note-56) It is estimated that complete vaccination, from birth to adolescence, of all US children born in a given year would save 33,000 lives and prevent 14 million infections. [[57]](#cite_note-57) Some argue that these reductions in infectious disease are a result of improved sanitation and hygiene (rather than vaccination), or that these diseases were already in decline before the introduction of specific vaccines. These claims are not supported by scientific data; the incidence of vaccine-preventable diseases tended to fluctuate over time until the introduction of specific vaccines, at which point the incidence dropped to near zero. A [Centers for Disease Control](/w/index.php?title=Centers_for_Disease_Control&action=edit&redlink=1) website aimed at countering common misconceptions about vaccines argued, "Are we expected to believe that better sanitation caused incidence of each disease to drop, just at the time a vaccine for that disease was introduced?" [[58]](#cite_note-CDC:_common_misconceptions-58) Other critics argue that the immunity granted by vaccines is only temporary and requires boosters, whereas those who survive the disease become permanently immune. [[5]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-5) As discussed below, the philosophies of some [alternative medicine](#Alternative_medicine) practitioners are incompatible with the idea that vaccines are effective. [[59]](#cite_note-Ernst-59) Population health[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=8)] Incomplete vaccine coverage increases the risk of disease for the entire population, including those who have been vaccinated, because it reduces [herd immunity](/w/index.php?title=Herd_immunity&action=edit&redlink=1). Herd immunity lessens this vulnerability if all the children are vaccinated. Increasing herd immunity during an outbreak or risk of outbreak is perhaps the most widely accepted justification for mass vaccination. When a new vaccine is introduced mass vaccination helps increase coverage rapidly. [[62]](#cite_note-62) If enough of a population is vaccinated, herd immunity takes effect, decreasing risk to people who cannot receive vaccines because they are too young or old, immunocompromised, or have severe allergies to the ingredients in the vaccine. [[63]](#cite_note-63). The outcome for people with compromised immune systems who get infected is often worse than that of the general population. [[64]](#cite_note-64) Necessity[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=9)] In many countries, reductions in the use of some vaccines were followed by increases in the diseases' morbidity and mortality. [[65]](#cite_note-Gangarosa_pertussis-65) [[66]](#cite_note-Allen_herd-66) According to the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/w/index.php?title=Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention&action=edit&redlink=1), continued high levels of vaccine coverage are necessary to prevent resurgence of diseases that have been nearly eliminated. [[67]](#cite_note-CDC_stop-67) Pertussis remains a major health problem in developing countries, where mass vaccination is not practiced; the World Health Organization estimates it caused 294,000 deaths in 2002. [[68]](#cite_note-68) Safety[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=10)] Few deny the vast improvements vaccination has made to public health; a more common concern is their safety. [[69]](#cite_note-LancetID-69) As with any medical treatment, there is a potential for vaccines to cause serious complications, such as severe allergic reactions, [[70]](#cite_note-70) but unlike most other medical interventions, vaccines are given to healthy people and so a higher standard of safety is expected. [[71]](#cite_note-71) While serious complications from vaccinations are possible, they are extremely rare and much less common than similar risks from the diseases they prevent. [[58]](#cite_note-CDC:_common_misconceptions-58) As the success of immunization programs increases and the incidence of disease decreases, public attention shifts away from the risks of disease to the risk of vaccination, [[72]](#cite_note-BH-72) and it becomes challenging for health authorities to preserve public support for vaccination programs, as parents may feel they have nothing to lose by not vaccinating their children. [[73]](#cite_note-73) If enough people hope to become [free-riders](/w/index.php?title=Free_rider_problem&action=edit&redlink=1), gaining the benefits of [herd immunity](/w/index.php?title=Herd_immunity&action=edit&redlink=1) without vaccination, vaccination levels may drop to a level where herd immunity ceases to exist. [[74]](#cite_note-74) [[75]](#cite_note-75) Unsubstantiated concerns about immunization safety often follow a pattern. First, some investigators suggest that a medical condition of increasing prevalence or unknown cause is an adverse effect of vaccination. The initial study and subsequent studies by the same group have inadequate methodology - typically a poorly controlled or uncontrolled [case series](/w/index.php?title=Case_series&action=edit&redlink=1). A premature announcement is made about the alleged adverse effect, resonating with individuals suffering from the condition, and underestimating the potential harm of forgoing vaccination to those whom the vaccine could protect. Other groups attempt to replicate the initial study but fail to get the same results. Finally, it takes several years to regain public confidence in the vaccine. [[72]](#cite_note-BH-72) Adverse effects ascribed to vaccines typically have an unknown origin, an increasing [incidence](/w/index.php?title=Incidence_(epidemiology)&action=edit&redlink=1), some [biological plausibility](/w/index.php?title=Biological_plausibility&action=edit&redlink=1), occurrences close to the time of vaccination, and dreaded outcomes. [[76]](#cite_note-76) In almost all cases, the spread of such concerns is limited by cultural boundaries: English speakers worry about one vaccine causing autism, while French speakers worry about another vaccine causing multiple sclerosis, and Nigerians worry that a third vaccine causes infertility. [[77]](#cite_note-77) Autism controversies[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=11)] Thiomersal[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=12)] US) is an [antifungal](/w/index.php?title=Antifungal&action=edit&redlink=1) preservative used in small amounts in some multi-dose vaccines (where the same vial is opened and used for multiple patients) to prevent contamination of the vaccine. [[78]](#cite_note-Baker-78) Despite thiomersal's efficacy, the use of thiomersal is controversial because it contains [mercury](/w/index.php?title=Mercury_(element)&action=edit&redlink=1). As a result, in 1999, the [Centers for Disease Control](/w/index.php?title=Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention&action=edit&redlink=1) (CDC) and the [American Academy of Pediatrics](/w/index.php?title=American_Academy_of_Pediatrics&action=edit&redlink=1) (AAP) asked vaccine makers to remove [thiomersal](/w/index.php?title=Thiomersal&action=edit&redlink=1) from vaccines as quickly as possible on the [precautionary principle](/w/index.php?title=Precautionary_principle&action=edit&redlink=1). Thiomersal is now absent from all common US and European vaccines, except for some preparations of [influenza vaccine](/w/index.php?title=Influenza_vaccine&action=edit&redlink=1). [[79]](#cite_note-Offit-79) (Trace amounts remain in some vaccines due to production processes, at an approximate maximum of 1 microgramme, around 15% of the average daily mercury intake in the US for adults and 2.5% of the daily level considered tolerable by the [WHO](/wiki/World_Health_Organization). [[80]](#cite_note-80) [[81]](#cite_note-81)) The action sparked concern that thiomersal could have been responsible for autism. [[79]](#cite_note-Offit-79) The idea is now considered disproven, as incidence rates for autism increased steadily even after thiomersal was removed from childhood vaccines. [[82]](#cite_note-Gerber-82) Currently there is no accepted scientific evidence that exposure to thiomersal is a factor in causing autism. [[83]](#cite_note-83) Since 2000, parents in the United States have pursued legal compensation from a federal fund arguing that thiomersal caused autism in their children. [[84]](#cite_note-Sugarman-84) A 2004 [Institute of Medicine](/w/index.php?title=Institute_of_Medicine&action=edit&redlink=1) (IOM) committee favored rejecting any causal relationship between thiomersal-containing vaccines and autism. [[85]](#cite_note-ISRC-85) MMR vaccine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=13)] In the UK, the [MMR vaccine](/w/index.php?title=MMR_vaccine&action=edit&redlink=1) was the subject of controversy after the publication in [The Lancet](/wiki/The_Lancet) of a 1998 paper by [Andrew Wakefield](/w/index.php?title=Andrew_Wakefield&action=edit&redlink=1) and others reporting case histories of 12 children mostly with [autism spectrum disorders](/w/index.php?title=Autism_spectrum&action=edit&redlink=1) with onset soon after administration of the vaccine. [[86]](#cite_note-86) At a 1998 press conference, Wakefield suggested that giving children the vaccines in three separate doses would be safer than a single vaccination. This suggestion was not supported by the paper, and several subsequent peer-reviewed studies have failed to show any association between the vaccine and autism. [[87]](#cite_note-NHS-87) It later emerged that Wakefield had received funding from litigants against vaccine manufacturers and that he had not informed colleagues or medical authorities of his [conflict of interest](/w/index.php?title=Conflict_of_interest&action=edit&redlink=1); [[88]](#cite_note-88) had this been known, publication in The Lancet would not have taken place in the way that it did. [[89]](#cite_note-89) Wakefield has been heavily criticized on scientific grounds and for triggering a decline in vaccination rates [[90]](#cite_note-90) (vaccination rates in the UK dropped to 80% in the years following the study), [[91]](#cite_note-Alazraki11-91) as well as on ethical grounds for the way the research was conducted. [[92]](#cite_note-paid_children-92) In 2004, the MMR-and-autism interpretation of the paper was formally retracted by 10 of Wakefield's 12 coauthors, [[93]](#cite_note-93) and in 2010 The Lancet's editors fully retracted the paper. [[94]](#cite_note-94) Wakefield was struck off the [UK medical register](/w/index.php?title=General_Medical_Council&action=edit&redlink=1), with a statement identifying deliberate falsification in the research published in The Lancet, [[95]](#cite_note-gmc-uk_Wakefield_SPM-95) and is barred from practising medicine in the UK. [[96]](#cite_note-MeikleBoseley-96) The CDC, [[97]](#cite_note-97) the IOM of the [National Academy of Sciences](/w/index.php?title=United_States_National_Academy_of_Sciences&action=edit&redlink=1), [[85]](#cite_note-ISRC-85) and the UK [National Health Service](/w/index.php?title=National_Health_Service&action=edit&redlink=1) [[98]](#cite_note-98) have all concluded that there is no evidence of a link between the MMR vaccine and autism. A systematic review by the [Cochrane Library](/w/index.php?title=Cochrane_Library&action=edit&redlink=1) concluded that there is no credible link between the MMR vaccine and autism, that MMR has prevented diseases that still carry a heavy burden of death and complications, that the lack of confidence in MMR has damaged public health, and that the design and reporting of safety outcomes in MMR vaccine studies are largely inadequate. [[99]](#cite_note-pmid22336803-99) In 2009, [The Sunday Times](/w/index.php?title=The_Sunday_Times&action=edit&redlink=1) reported that Wakefield had manipulated patient data and misreported results in his 1998 paper, creating the appearance of a link with autism. [[100]](#cite_note-100) A 2011 article in the [British Medical Journal](/w/index.php?title=BMJ&action=edit&redlink=1) described how the data in the study had been falsified by Wakefield so that it would arrive at a predetermined conclusion. [[101]](#cite_note-101) An accompanying editorial in the same journal described Wakefield's work as an "elaborate [fraud](/w/index.php?title=Fraud&action=edit&redlink=1)" that led to lower vaccination rates, putting hundreds of thousands of children at risk and diverting energy and money away from research into the true cause of autism. [[102]](#cite_note-102) A special court convened in the United States to review claims under the [National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_court&action=edit&redlink=1) ruled on February 12, 2009 that parents of autistic children are not entitled to compensation in their contention that certain vaccines caused autism in their children. [[103]](#cite_note-103) "Vaccine overload"[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=14)] "Vaccine overload", a non-medical term, is the notion that giving many vaccines at once may overwhelm or weaken a child's immature immune system and lead to adverse effects. [[104]](#cite_note-Hilton-104) Despite scientific evidence that strongly contradicts this idea, [[82]](#cite_note-Gerber-82) some parents of autistic children believe that vaccine overload causes autism. [[105]](#cite_note-105) The resulting controversy has caused many parents to delay or avoid immunizing their children. [[104]](#cite_note-Hilton-104) Such parental misperceptions are major obstacles towards immunization of children. [[106]](#cite_note-106) The concept of vaccine overload is flawed on several levels. [[82]](#cite_note-Gerber-82) Despite the increase in the number of vaccines over recent decades, improvements in vaccine design have reduced the immunologic load from vaccines; the total number of immunological components in the 14 vaccines administered to US children in 2009 is less than 10% of what it was in the 7 vaccines given in 1980. [[82]](#cite_note-Gerber-82) A study published in 2013 found no correlation between autism and the [antigen](/w/index.php?title=Antigen&action=edit&redlink=1) number in the vaccines the children were administered up to the age of two. Of the 1,008 children in the study, one quarter of those diagnosed with autism were born between 1994 and 1999, when the routine vaccine schedule could contain more than 3,000 antigens (in a single shot of [DTP vaccine](/w/index.php?title=DTP_vaccine&action=edit&redlink=1)). The vaccine schedule in 2012 contains several more vaccines, but the number of antigens the child is exposed to by the age of two is 315. [[107]](#cite_note-107) [[108]](#cite_note-108) Vaccines pose a very small immunologic load compared to the pathogens naturally encountered by a child in a typical year; [[82]](#cite_note-Gerber-82) common childhood conditions such as fevers and [middle-ear infections](/w/index.php?title=Otitis_media&action=edit&redlink=1) pose a much greater challenge to the immune system than vaccines, [[109]](#cite_note-109) and studies have shown that vaccinations, even multiple concurrent vaccinations, do not weaken the immune system [[82]](#cite_note-Gerber-82) or compromise overall immunity. [[110]](#cite_note-110) The lack of evidence supporting the vaccine overload hypothesis, combined with these findings directly contradicting it, has led to the conclusion that currently recommended vaccine programs do not "overload" or weaken the immune system. [[72]](#cite_note-BH-72) [[111]](#cite_note-111) [[112]](#cite_note-Hackett-Offit-112) [[113]](#cite_note-Schneeweiss-113) Any experiment based on withholding vaccines from children has been considered unethical, [[114]](#cite_note-114) and observational studies would likely be [confounded](/w/index.php?title=Confounding&action=edit&redlink=1) by differences in the health care-seeking behaviours of under-vaccinated children. Thus, no study directly comparing rates of autism in vaccinated and unvaccinated children has been done. However, the concept of vaccine overload is biologically implausible, vaccinated and unvaccinated children have the same immune response to non-vaccine-related infections, and autism is not an immune-mediated disease, so claims that vaccines could cause it by overloading the immune system go against current knowledge of the [pathogenesis](/w/index.php?title=Pathogenesis&action=edit&redlink=1) of autism. As such, the idea that vaccines cause autism has been effectively dismissed by the weight of current evidence. [[82]](#cite_note-Gerber-82) Prenatal infection[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=15)] There is evidence that [schizophrenia](/w/index.php?title=Schizophrenia&action=edit&redlink=1) is associated with prenatal exposure to [rubella](/w/index.php?title=Rubella&action=edit&redlink=1), [influenza](/w/index.php?title=Influenza&action=edit&redlink=1), and [toxoplasmosis](/w/index.php?title=Toxoplasmosis&action=edit&redlink=1) infection. For example, one study found a sevenfold increased risk of schizophrenia when mothers were exposed to influenza in the first trimester of gestation. This may have public health implications, as strategies for preventing infection include vaccination, simple hygiene, and, in the case of toxoplasmosis, antibiotics. [[115]](#cite_note-115) Based on studies in animal models, theoretical concerns have been raised about a possible link between schizophrenia and maternal immune response activated by virus antigens; a 2009 review concluded that there was insufficient evidence to recommend routine use of [trivalent influenza vaccine](/w/index.php?title=Influenza_vaccine&action=edit&redlink=1) during the first trimester of pregnancy, but that the vaccine was still recommended outside the first trimester and in special circumstances such as pandemics or in women with certain other conditions. [[116]](#cite_note-116) The CDC's [Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices](/w/index.php?title=Advisory_Committee_on_Immunization_Practices&action=edit&redlink=1), the [American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists](/w/index.php?title=American_Congress_of_Obstetricians_and_Gynecologists&action=edit&redlink=1), and the [American Academy of Family Physicians](/w/index.php?title=American_Academy_of_Family_Physicians&action=edit&redlink=1) all recommend routine flu shots for pregnant women, for several reasons: [[117]](#cite_note-ACIP2007-117) - their risk for serious influenza-related medical complications during the last two trimesters; - their greater rates for flu-related hospitalizations compared to non-pregnant women; - the possible transfer of maternal anti-influenza antibodies to children, protecting the children from the flu; and - several studies that found no harm to pregnant women or their children from the vaccinations. Despite this recommendation, only 16% of healthy pregnant US women surveyed in 2005 had been vaccinated against the flu. [[117]](#cite_note-ACIP2007-117) Aluminium[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=16)] [Aluminium](/w/index.php?title=Aluminium&action=edit&redlink=1) compounds are used as [immunologic adjuvants](/w/index.php?title=Immunologic_adjuvant&action=edit&redlink=1) to increase the effectiveness of many vaccines. The aluminium in vaccines simulates or causes small amounts of tissue damage, driving the body to respond more powerfully to what it sees as a serious infection and promoting the development of a lasting immune response. [[118]](#cite_note-Baylor-118) [[119]](#cite_note-119) In some cases these compounds have been associated with redness, itching, and low-grade fever, [[118]](#cite_note-Baylor-118) but the use of aluminium in vaccines has not been associated with serious adverse events. [[120]](#cite_note-Francois-120) In some cases, aluminium-containing vaccines are associated with [macrophagic myofasciitis](/w/index.php?title=Macrophagic_myofasciitis&action=edit&redlink=1) (MMF), localized microscopic [lesions](/w/index.php?title=Lesion&action=edit&redlink=1) containing aluminium salts that persist for up to 8 years. However, recent case-controlled studies have found no specific clinical symptoms in individuals with biopsies showing MMF, and there is no evidence that aluminium-containing vaccines are a serious health risk or justify changes to immunization practice. [[120]](#cite_note-Francois-120) Anthrax vaccines[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=17)] When the U.S. military began requiring its troops to receive the [anthrax vaccine](/w/index.php?title=Anthrax_vaccine&action=edit&redlink=1), multiple US military troops refused to do so, which led to threats of military [courts martial](/w/index.php?title=Courts-martial_in_the_United_States&action=edit&redlink=1). [[121]](#cite_note-121) Swine flu vaccine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=18)] During the [2009 flu pandemic](/w/index.php?title=2009_flu_pandemic&action=edit&redlink=1), significant controversy broke out regarding whether the [2009 H1N1 flu vaccine](/w/index.php?title=2009_flu_pandemic_vaccine&action=edit&redlink=1) was safe in, among other countries, [France](/w/index.php?title=France&action=edit&redlink=1). Numerous different French groups publicly criticized the vaccine as potentially dangerous. [[122]](#cite_note-122) Other safety concerns[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=19)] Other safety concerns about vaccines have been published on the Internet, in informal meetings, in books, and at symposia. These include hypotheses that vaccination can cause [sudden vaccinations [bovine spongiform encephalopathy](/w/index.php?title=Bovine_spongiform_encephalopathy&action=edit&redlink=1), [hepatitis C virus](/w/index.php?title=Hepatitis_C_virus&action=edit&redlink=1), and [HIV](/w/index.php?title=HIV&action=edit&redlink=1). These hypotheses have been investigated, with the conclusion that currently used vaccines meet high safety standards and that criticism of vaccine safety in the popular press is not justified. [[113]](#cite_note-Schneeweiss-113) Large well-controlled epidemiologic studies have been conducted and the results do not support the hypothesis that vaccines cause chronic diseases. Furthermore, some vaccines are probably more likely to prevent or modify than cause or exacerbate autoimmune diseases. [[112]](#cite_note-Hackett-Offit-112) Policy controversies[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=20)] Individual liberty[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=21)] Compulsory vaccination policies have been controversial as long as they have existed, with opponents of mandatory vaccinations arguing that governments should not infringe on an individual's freedom to make medical decisions for themselves or their children, while proponents of compulsory vaccination cite the well documented public health benefits of vaccination. [[5]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-5) [[123]](#cite_note-123) Others argue that, for compulsory vaccination to effectively prevent disease, there must be not only available vaccines and a population willing to immunize, but also sufficient ability to decline vaccination on grounds of personal belief. [[124]](#cite_note-124) Vaccination policy involves complicated ethical issues, as unvaccinated individuals are more likely to contract and spread disease to people with weaker immune systems, such as young children and the elderly, and to other individuals in whom the vaccine has not been effective. However, mandatory vaccination policies raise ethical issues regarding parental rights and [informed consent](/w/index.php?title=Informed_consent&action=edit&redlink=1). [[125]](#cite_note-125) Children's rights[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=22)] Medical ethicist [Arthur Caplan](/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Caplan&action=edit&redlink=1) argues that children have a right to the best available medical care, including vaccines, regardless of parental feelings toward vaccines, saying "Arguments about medical freedom and choice are at odds with the human and constitutional rights of children. When parents won't protect them, governments must." [[126]](#cite_note-126) [[127]](#cite_note-127) A review of court cases from 1905 to 2016 found that, of the 9 courts that have heard cases regarding whether not vaccinating a child constitutes neglect, 7 have held vaccine refusal to be a form of child neglect. [[128]](#cite_note-128) To prevent the spread of disease by unvaccinated individuals, some schools and doctors' surgeries have prohibited unvaccinated children from being enrolled, even where not required by law. [[129]](#cite_note-129) [[130]](#cite_note-130) Refusal of doctors to treat unvaccinated children may cause harm to both the child and public health, and may be considered unethical, if the parents are unable to find another healthcare provider for the child. [[131]](#cite_note-131) Opinion on this is divided, with the largest professional association, the [American Academy of Pediatrics](/w/index.php?title=American_Academy_of_Pediatrics&action=edit&redlink=1), saying that exclusion of unvaccinated children may be an option under narrowly defined circumstances. [[132]](#cite_note-132) Others have questioned whether it is right to punish a child for parents' bad choices. [[133]](#cite_note-133) Religion[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=23)] Vaccination has been opposed on religious grounds ever since it was introduced. Some Christian opponents argued, when vaccination was first becoming widespread, that if God had decreed that someone should die of smallpox, it would be a sin to thwart God's will via vaccination. [[12]](#cite_note-Early-12) Religious opposition continues to the present day, on various grounds, raising ethical difficulties when the number of unvaccinated children threatens harm to the entire population. [[134]](#cite_note-May-134) Many governments allow parents to opt out of their children's otherwise mandatory vaccinations for religious reasons; some parents falsely claim religious beliefs to get vaccination exemptions. [[135]](#cite_note-135) The [Haredi burqa sect](/w/index.php?title=Haredi_burqa_sect&action=edit&redlink=1) in Israel opposed vaccinations and medical treatments on moral grounds, which led to the death of at least one baby from untreated influenza. [[136]](#cite_note-baby-136) Among early [Hasidic](/w/index.php?title=Hasidic&action=edit&redlink=1) leaders, Rabbi [Nachman of Breslov](/w/index.php?title=Nachman_of_Breslov&action=edit&redlink=1) (1772-1810) was known for his criticism of the doctors and medical treatments of his day. However, when the first vaccines were successfully introduced, he stated: "Every parent should have his children vaccinated within the first three months of life. Failure to do so is tantamount to murder. Even if they live far from the city and have to travel during the great winter cold, they should have the child vaccinated before three months." [[137]](#cite_note-137) In the United States, there are currently only three states (Mississippi, West Virginia, and California) that do not provide exemptions based on religious beliefs. [[138]](#cite_note-138) The cell cultures of some viral vaccines, and the virus of the [rubella](/w/index.php?title=Rubella&action=edit&redlink=1) vaccine, [[139]](#cite_note-pmid3890107-139) are derived from tissues taken from therapeutic abortions performed in the 1960s, leading to moral questions. For example, the [principle of double effect](/w/index.php?title=Principle_of_double_effect&action=edit&redlink=1), originated by [Thomas Aquinas](/w/index.php?title=Thomas_Aquinas&action=edit&redlink=1), holds that actions with both good and bad consequences are morally acceptable in specific circumstances, and the question is how this principle applies to vaccination. [[140]](#cite_note-140) The Vatican Curia has expressed concern about the rubella vaccine's embryonic cell origin, saying that Catholics have "a grave responsibility to use alternative vaccines and to make a conscientious objection with regard to those which have moral problems." [[141]](#cite_note-Vatican-141) The Vatican concluded that until an alternative becomes available, it is acceptable for [Catholics](/w/index.php?title=Catholic&action=edit&redlink=1) to use the existing vaccine, writing, "This is an unjust alternative choice, which must be eliminated as soon as possible." [[141]](#cite_note-Vatican-141) In the US, some parents claim fake religious exemptions when their real motivation for avoiding vaccines is supposed safety concerns. [[142]](#cite_note-cbs-fake-142) Alternative medicine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=24)] Many forms of [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) are based on philosophies that oppose vaccination (including [germ theory denialism](/w/index.php?title=Germ_theory_denialism&action=edit&redlink=1)) and have practitioners who voice their opposition. These include some elements of the [chiropractic](/wiki/Chiropractic) community, some [homeopaths](/wiki/Homeopathy), and [naturopaths](/wiki/Naturopathy). [[59]](#cite_note-Ernst-59) The reasons for this negative vaccination view are complicated and rest at least in part on the early philosophies that shaped the foundation of these groups. [[59]](#cite_note-Ernst-59) Chiropractic[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=25)] [Template:Globalize/North America](/w/index.php?title=Template:Globalize/North_America&action=edit&redlink=1) Historically, [chiropractic](/wiki/Chiropractic) strongly opposed vaccination based on its belief that all diseases were traceable to causes in the spine and therefore could not be affected by vaccines. [Daniel D. Palmer](/w/index.php?title=Daniel_David_Palmer&action=edit&redlink=1) (1845-1913), the founder of chiropractic, wrote: "It is the very height of absurdity to strive to 'protect' any person from smallpox or any other malady by inoculating them with a filthy animal poison." [[143]](#cite_note-Busse-143) Vaccination remains controversial within the profession. [[144]](#cite_note-Campbell-144) Most chiropractic writings on vaccination focus on its negative aspects; [[143]](#cite_note-Busse-143) A 1995 survey of US chiropractors found that about one third believed there was no scientific proof that immunization prevents disease. [[144]](#cite_note-Campbell-144) While the Canadian Chiropractic Association supports vaccination, [[143]](#cite_note-Busse-143) a survey in Alberta in 2002 found that 25% of chiropractors advised patients for, and 27% advised against, vaccinations for patients or for their children. [[145]](#cite_note-145) Although most chiropractic colleges try to teach about vaccination in a manner consistent with scientific evidence, several have faculty who seem to stress negative views. [[144]](#cite_note-Campbell-144) A survey of a 1999-2000 cross-section of students of [Canadian Memorial Chiropractic College](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Memorial_Chiropractic_College&action=edit&redlink=1) (CMCC), which does not formally teach anti-vaccination views, reported that fourth-year students opposed vaccination more strongly than did first-year students, with 29.4% of fourth-year students opposing vaccination. [[146]](#cite_note-146) A follow-up study on 2011-12 CMCC students found that pro-vaccination attitudes heavily predominated. Students reported support rates ranging from 84% to 90%. One of the study's authors proposed the change in attitude to be due to the lack of the previous influence of a "subgroup of some charismatic students who were enrolled at CMCC at the time, students who championed the Palmer postulates that advocated against the use of vaccination". [[147]](#cite_note-147) Policy positions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=26)] The [American Chiropractic Association](/w/index.php?title=American_Chiropractic_Association&action=edit&redlink=1) and the International Chiropractic Association support individual exemptions to compulsory vaccination laws. [[144]](#cite_note-Campbell-144) In March 2015, the Oregon Chiropractic Association invited [Andrew Wakefield](/w/index.php?title=Andrew_Wakefield&action=edit&redlink=1), chief author of a [fraudulent research paper](/w/index.php?title=MMR_vaccine_controversy&action=edit&redlink=1), to testify against Senate Bill 442, [[148]](#cite_note-Yoo-148) "a bill that would eliminate nonmedical exemptions from Oregon's school immunization law". [[149]](#cite_note-Yoo_canceled-149) The California Chiropractic Association lobbied against a 2015 bill ending belief exemptions for vaccines. They had also opposed a 2012 bill related to vaccination exemptions. [[150]](#cite_note-Mason-150) Homeopathy[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=27)] Several surveys have shown that some practitioners of [homeopathy](/wiki/Homeopathy), particularly homeopaths without any medical training, advise patients against vaccination. [[151]](#cite_note-151) For example, a survey of registered homeopaths in Austria found that only 28% considered immunization an important preventive measure, and 83% of homeopaths surveyed in Sydney, Australia, did not recommend vaccination. [[59]](#cite_note-Ernst-59) Many practitioners of [naturopathy](/wiki/Naturopathy) also oppose vaccination. [[59]](#cite_note-Ernst-59) [Homeopathic](/wiki/Homeopathy) "vaccines" (nosodes) are ineffective because they do not contain any active ingredients and thus do not stimulate the immune system. They can be dangerous if they take the place of effective treatments. [[152]](#cite_note-SciMed-152) Some medical organizations have taken action against nosodes. In Canada, the labeling of homeopathic nosodes require the statement: "This product is neither a vaccine nor an alternative to vaccination." [[153]](#cite_note-StopNosodes-153) Financial motives[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=28)] [Alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) proponents gain from promoting vaccine conspiracy theories through the sale of ineffective and expensive medications, supplements, and procedures such as [chelation therapy](/wiki/Chelation_therapy) and [hyperbaric oxygen therapy](/wiki/Hyperbaric_medicine), sold as able to cure the 'damage' caused by vaccines. [[154]](#cite_note-154) Homeopaths in particular gain through the promotion of water injections or 'nosodes' that they allege have a 'natural' vaccine-like effect. [[155]](#cite_note-155) Additional bodies with a vested interest in promoting the "unsafeness" of vaccines may include lawyers and legal groups organizing court cases and [class action](/w/index.php?title=Class_action&action=edit&redlink=1) lawsuits against vaccine providers. Conversely, alternative medicine providers have accused the vaccine industry of misrepresenting the safety and effectiveness of vaccines, covering up and suppressing information, and influencing health policy decisions for financial gain. [[5]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-5) In the late 20th century, vaccines were a product with low [profit margins](/w/index.php?title=Profit_margin&action=edit&redlink=1), [[156]](#cite_note-Sheridan-156) and the number of companies involved in vaccine manufacture declined. In addition to low profits and liability risks, manufacturers complained about low prices paid for vaccines by the CDC and other US government agencies. [[157]](#cite_note-157) In the early 21st century, the vaccine market greatly improved with the approval of the vaccine [Prevnar](/w/index.php?title=Pneumococcal_conjugate_vaccine&action=edit&redlink=1), along with a small number of other high-priced [blockbuster vaccines](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_drug&action=edit&redlink=1), such as [Gardasil](/w/index.php?title=Gardasil&action=edit&redlink=1) and [Pediarix](/w/index.php?title=Pediarix&action=edit&redlink=1), which each had sales revenues of over $1 billion in 2008. [[156]](#cite_note-Sheridan-156) War[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=29)] The United States has a very complex history with [compulsory vaccination](/w/index.php?title=Vaccination_policy&action=edit&redlink=1), particularly in enforcing compulsory vaccinations both domestically and abroad to protect American soldiers during times of war. There are hundreds of thousands of examples of soldier deaths that were not the result of combat wounds, but were instead from disease. [[158]](#cite_note-:0-158) Among wars with high death tolls from disease is the Civil War where an estimated 620,000 soldiers died from disease. American soldiers in other countries have spread diseases that ultimately disrupted entire societies and healthcare systems with famine and poverty. [[158]](#cite_note-:0-158) Spanish-American War[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vaccine_controversies&action=edit§ion=30)] The [Spanish-American War](/w/index.php?title=Spanish%E2%80%93American_War&action=edit&redlink=1) began in April 1898 and ended in August 1898. During this time the United States gained control of Cuba, Puerto Rico, and the Philippines from Spain. As a [military police power](/w/index.php?title=Military_police&action=edit&redlink=1) and as colonizers the United States took a very hands-on approach in administering healthcare particularly vaccinations to natives during the invasion and conquest of these countries. [[158]](#cite_note-:0-158) Although the Spanish-American War occurred during the era of ["bacteriological revolution"](/w/index.php?title=Germ_theory_of_disease&action=edit&redlink=1) where knowledge of disease was bolstered by [germ theory](/w/index.php?title=Germ_theory_of_disease&action=edit&redlink=1), more than half of the soldier casualties in this war were from disease. [[158]](#cite_note-:0-158) Unknowingly, American soldiers acted as agents of disease transmission, fostering bacteria in their haphazardly made camps. These soldiers invaded Cuba, Puerto Rico, and the Philippines and connected parts of these countries that had never before been connected due to the countries sparse nature thereby beginning epidemics. [[158]](#cite_note-:0-158) The mobility of American soldiers around these countries encouraged a newfound mobility of disease that quickly infected natives. Military personnel used Rudyard's Kipling's poem " [The White Man's Burden](/w/index.php?title=The_White_Man%27s_Burden&action=edit&redlink=1)" to explain their imperialistic actions in Cuba, the Philippines, and Puerto Rico and the need for the United States to help the "dark-skinned Barbarians" [[158]](#cite_note-:0-158) reach modern sanitary standards. American actions abroad before, during, and after the war emphasized a need for proper sanitation habits especially on behalf of the natives. Natives who refuse to oblige with American health standards and procedures risked fines or imprisonment. [[158]](#cite_note-:0-158) One penalty in Puerto Rico included a $10 fine for a failure to vaccinate and an additional $5 fine for any day you continue to be unvaccinated, refusal to pay resulted in ten or more days of imprisonment. If entire villages refused the army's current sanitation policy at any given time they risked being burnt to the ground in order to preserve the health and safety of soldiers from endemic smallpox and yellow fever. [[158]](#cite_note-:0-158) Vaccines were forcibly administered to the Puerto Ricans, Cubans, and Filipinos. Military personnel in Puerto Rico provided Public Health services that culminated in military orders that mandated vaccinations for children before they were six months old, as well as a general vaccination order. [[158]](#cite_note-:0-158) By the end of 1899 in Puerto Rico alone the U.S. military and other hired native vaccinators called practicantes, vaccinated an estimated 860,000 natives in a five-month period. This period began the United States' movement toward an expansion of medical practices that included "tropical medicine" in an attempt to protect the lives of soldiers abroad.
